string.text: Źmiescavany ledź nižej pa race ad źlićcia rekaŭ Avier i Łammier, horad Štrajsien viadomy svaim revalucyjnym ducham i pieramienlivym minułym. U horadzie znachodzicca nievialiki ŭniviersitet i miedyčnaja škoła, sumna viadomaja tym, što vypuskaje vučniaŭ, jakija nie prytrymvajucca starych šlachoŭ. Niekali Štrajsien mieŭ svaju ŭłasnuju haradzkuju chartyju, što davała šmat palohak i mahčymasć abirać svaich kiraŭnikoŭ, ale jana była skasavana ŭ vyniku ŭhody z Hrafiniaj Ludmiłaj Alptraŭm, jakaja vyratavała horad ad revalucyi pad čałom studentaŭ. Univiersitet praciahvaje funkcyjavać, ale ŭspaminy pra čystki paśla hvałtoŭnaha pryhniečańnia Alptraŭmam dahetul śviežyja ŭ pamiaci bolšaści žycharoŭ. Tut pracuje pieraprava, jakaja zabiaśpiečvaje puć praz Avier.

Lenhienfeld zjaŭlajecca asnoŭnaj vołaściu Hrafini Karmiłły fon Zaks. Tutejšyja dla pražytka łoviać rybu ŭ race Avier. Sušać i pradajuć jaje razam sa svajoj žyviołaj, kab nažyć bahaćcie. Taksama tutaka znachodzicca pieraprava, jakaja palahčaje ruch i handal praz raku Avier dy źbiraje padatki dla svajho šlachciča.

Na zachodniaj miažy Lesu Płaču znachodzicca vioska Bisvanh. Ludzi tut vyžyvajuć za košt taho, što mohuć vyhadavać, i handlujuć, kab nabyć toje, što nia mohuć vyrabić. U adroźnieńnie ad bolšaści avierlandaŭ, ich blizkasć da nibyta praklataha lesu zrabiła ich zababonnymi; čužyncam ciažka zasłužyć ich davier.

Źmiescavany na skryžavańni darohaŭ Staryja Šlachi Hnomaŭ, horad Chajdek byŭ spradviečna pabudavany hnomami ŭ časy roskvitu ichniaha haspadarstva niekalki tysiačahodździaŭ tamu. Małalikija zachavanyja pabudovy hnomaŭ dahetul vykarystoŭvajucca ludźmi, i zjaŭlajucca žyvym śviedčańniem architekturnych standartaŭ starejšaj rasy. Pa čutkach, pad Chajdekam znachodzicca mnostva katakombaŭ hnomaŭ, napoŭnienych staražytnymi skarbami i artefaktami, jakija tolki i čakajuć, kab ich znajšli i zabrali.

U atačeńni rova i kamiennaha častakołu znachodzicca horad Kolmfahr. Heta ścipły horad. Horadam i jaho navakollem kiruje Baron Zihmund Hindenbierh, jaki pilnuje za ŭsim z Zamka Hindenburh, źmiescavanaha na susiednim uzhorku. Pieraprava absłuhoŭvaje padarožnikaŭ, jakija žadajuć pierasiekčy raku Rajk, jakaja ci ciače na poŭdzień, ci na poŭnač u Averland.

Zjaŭlajučysia nievialikim horadam u paŭdniovaj častcy Averlanda, Łoninhbruk słužyć najvažniejšym prypynkam dla handlaroŭ, što vandrujuć pa race Rajk, abo ŭniz pa race da Maryjenburha i Vialikaha Akijana, abo ŭharu pa race da Haspadarstvaŭ Hnomaŭ. Taksama heta adzin z małalikich šlachoŭ, što viadzie da Pieravału Čornaje Połymia i prachodzić praz Łoninhbruk. U vyniku hetych mierkantylnych intaresaŭ ekanomika horada zaležyć ad handlu, jaki zabiaśpiečvajuć hetyja maršruty. Aproč taho, horad tolki prodaje žyviołu. U horadzie daminujuć vialiki zajezny dom Skryžavanyja Klučy i chram Viareny, samy vialiki chram u horadzie. Łoninhbruk, na žal, taksama nosić imia Łoninhbruk Rubinavy, bo sumna viadomy nizkajakasnym vinom.

Radzima Baranesy Aldar, niepieraborlivaja vioska Biernłoch najbolej viadomaja svaim Biernłoskim Ćviordym Syram. Žychary vioski hałoŭnym čynam razvodziać kozaŭ dziela miasa, syru dy handlu na darozie miž Ahbajtienam i Chajdekam.

Doki ŭ Chochšliben paznačajuć kaniec Vierchniaha Rajka dla ruchu karabloŭ. Chacia raka praciahvajecca vyšej u hory na šmatlikija mili, paśla hetaha miesca parohi, vadaspady i ŭźnimańni robiacca zanadta niebiaśpiečnymi dla padarožžaŭ. U vyniku ŭ horadzie zvyčajna źbirajecca mnostva łodak i karabloŭ, jakija handlujuć tavarami, što iduć ci prychodziać z Horaŭ Rohu Śvietu.

Ahbajtien - heta vialikaja vioska, jakaja słužyć jak handlovym, hetak i relihijnym centram u Paŭdniovym Averlandzie. Talibenpłac, centar Ahbajtiena, - heta vialiki plac, na jakim Ahbajtien pravodzić svoj štodzionny kirmaš, źmiescavany na skryžavańni šlachoŭ Łoninhbruka, Chochšlibena i Chajdeka. Na paŭnočnym kancy placu znachodziacca chramy Zihmara, Ulryka i Viareny. Kruhły, pabudavany z dreva chram Taala i Rai - adzin z najbujniejšych u Paŭdniovaj Impieryi i adzin z małalikich, źmiescavanych u kamiennych ścienach horada. Žychary Ahbajtiena hałoŭnym čynam zjaŭlajucca paśladoŭnikami Taala i Rai.

Maleńkaja vioska Zel była zasnavana na adnym z siłkavalnych prytokaŭ Błakitnaj Miažy. Chacia vada tut zanadta płytkaja dla vialikich handlovych karabloŭ, zvyčajnych dla inšych rek, viaskoŭcy ŭžyvajuć nievialikija čoŭny i płyty dla pieravozki ŭradžaju ŭ Fallenbłat, dzie jaho lha pradać Paŭroślikam ci pieravieźci dalej uniz pa race.

Dzitfurc dastaŭlaje ziernie ŭ navakolnyja sieliščy, a taksama ŭ kramy Funcyha. Tutejšyja žychary z padozram staviacca da pryjezdžych, aścierahajučysia, što jany špijony paŭroślikaŭ ci jašče horš; vandroŭniki z uschodniaha Šcirlanda. Hraf fon Hajn najmaje mnohich svaich žaŭnioraŭ u Dzitfurcy, šmatlikija ź ich viartajucca dadomu, kali vychodziać na piensiju, u vyniku z mužčynaŭ Dzitfurca atrymvajucca vydatnyja vajary.

Bibierchof lažyć u atačeńni hustoha lesu ŭ niekalkich kiłamietrach da poŭdnia ad Vurtbada. Jaho žychary pa-majstersku vykarystoŭvajuć siakiery, jak dla narychtoŭki vysakajakasnaj draŭniny sa starych drevaŭ vakoł, hetak i dla abarony svaich łahieraŭ ad škodnikaŭ i vypadkovych razbojnikaŭ. Draŭnina z Bidierchofa karystajecca popytam u šlachty Vurtbada, pakolki havorać, što jaje ciomnaje adcieńnie praklata dla ŭsiakaha vampira, jakomu nie paščaściła być prakołatym hetym drevam.

Julbach raźmieščany na paŭdarozie miž Rekami Šcir i Avier. Jon raźmieščany ŭ dalinie, zacienienaj Uzhorkami Zaja, dzie ŭzdoŭž Darohi Nuln volna švendajucca aviečki. Les Nattarn, źmiescavany ŭ niekalkich milach da zachadu, słužyć adnačasna krynicaj bahaćcia i zababonaŭ, pakolki navat u samyja chałodnyja zimovyja nočy, kali i nasiakomyja, i źviary śpiać, udalečyni čutny hruk kapytoŭ.

Vobiervil - nievialikaja rybackaja vioska ŭ niekalkich milach da zachadu ad Vurtbada. Šlachi ŭ Vobiervil - nia bolš za piešachodnyja ściežki, pakolki vialikaja častka handlu i padarožžaŭ ažyćciaŭlajecca pa race. Vioska ŭ peŭnaj stupieni abaroniena Račnymi Nahladnikami, jakija časta naviedvajuć Šcir, ale ŭ cełym žycharam davodzicca samim dužacca z bandytami i źvieraludźmi z ciomnaha lesu.

Tarschof raźmieščany na paŭnočnaj uskrainie Ŭzhorkaŭ Šcirchuhiel. Vioska karystajecca vialikim popytam u handlaroŭ, jakija vandrujuć miž Vurtbadam i Viordenam pa Starym Šlachu Hnomaŭ. U vyniku, amal kožnaja chata ŭ vioscy pretenduje na zvańnie karčmy, choć haścinnasć vielmi adroźnivajecca, i vandroŭniki mohuć apynucca na kučy siena, a nie na narmalnym łožku.

Flensburh maleńki kirmašovy horad, jaki mieścicca la Ŭzhorkaŭ Zaja na zachadzie ad Šcirchuhiela. Uzhorki idealna padychodziać dla pašy aviečak, a ekanomika horada zasnavana na vytvorčaści poŭści, baraniny i jahniaciny. Horad taksama viadomy ŭ kraje tym, što ŭ im znachodzicca bujny chram Šalli.

Łochien zjaŭlajecca daččynym sieliščam susiedniaha horada Flensburh. U vioski hałoŭnym čynam žyvuć ziemlaroby, jakija zabiaśpiečvajuć horad zierniem. Łochien znachodzicca pad abaronaj Hrafini Pietry Charden i jaje vajaroŭ.

Francen - nia varty ŭvahi horad, źmiescavany ŭ cieni bujnych sieliščaŭ pablizu. Jon viadzie aktyŭnuju rybnuju łoŭlu ŭ Łammiery i Aviery, a taksama moža pachvalicca duža karystanaj pierapravaj praz Łammier, jakaja dazvalaje vandroŭnikam praciahnuć šlach na zachad u Russbach.

Chrobak - heta nievialikaja hramada ziemlarobaŭ, što lažyć u nizinnych zabahnienych miaścinach miž rekami Maćcid, Łammier i Avier. Naturalnaje abvadnieńnie, što zabiaśpiečvajecca rekami, zrabiła hety kraj idealnaj vornaj ziamloju, a blizkija Francen i Avierchajm karystajucca ščodrymi dastaŭkami ziernia z vioski.

Russbach - heta viosačka, źmiescavanaja ŭ dziarnovych bałotach da poŭdnia ad uzhorkaŭ Šcirchuhiel. Prosta pad pavierchniaj ziamli znachodziacca hłybokija hlinianyja karjery, i žychary Russbach zarablajuć na žyćcio zdabyčaj budaŭničaha materyjału. Vandroŭniki paznajuć, što jany znachodziacca niedaloka ad vioski, kali adčuvajuć zjedlivy pach dymu ad piečak mularaŭ.

Cytadel Chalštied znachodzicca na paŭdniova-ŭschodnim ŭskrajku ŭzhorkaŭ Šcirchuhiel i zjaŭlajecca pieravalnym punktam dla Darožnych Nahladnikaŭ kraja. Spačatku heta byŭ falvarak, jaki prynaležaŭ niejkamu daŭno zabytamu šlachciču, z časam jon rabiŭsia ŭsio bolej i bolej umacavanym, bo kožny nastupny ŭłaśnik imknuŭsia abaranić jaje žycharoŭ ad bandytaŭ i zielenaskurych z susiedniaha Lesu Altern. Urešcie jon pierajšoŭ u ruki haspadarstva i byŭ aficyjna pieraŭtvorany ŭ krepasć-načleh dla Darožnych Nahladnikaŭ, jaki achoŭvajuć miascovasć.

Raab - heta vioska, jakaja naturalnaj čynam utvaryłasia vakoł Śviacilišča Šalli. Źmiescavanaja na źlićci šmatlikich šlachoŭ, jana była naturalnym miescam dla prydarožnaha śviacilišča - miesca, dzie padarožniki mahli spynicca, adpačyć i paprasić dabrasłavieńni na svoj šlach. Adnojčy handlar vinom, jaki časta naviedvaŭ śviacilišča, zrazumieŭ kaštoŭnasć hetkaha zručnaha zvyčaju i pabudavaŭ na skryžavańni karčmu. Nieŭzabavie vakoł jaje ŭtvaryłasia hramada, i paŭstała vioska Raab.

Tennek - vioska vinarobaŭ, jakija zabiaśpiečvajuć miascovy aporny punkt Darožnych Nahladnikaŭ u Cytadeli Chalštied. Tennek utvaryŭsia z siemjaŭ abaviaźnikaŭ, jakija kłapacilisia pra tutejšuju ziamlu i šlachtu z falvarku Chalštied. Kali falvarak Chalštied pieratvaryŭsia ŭ Cytadel Chalštied, jany stali volnymi ludźmi i vyrašyli apracoŭvać svaje ziemli dla prodažu sadaviny i napojaŭ. Darožnyja Nahladniki z Cytadeli Chalštied časta prymajuć niekalki hałonaŭ vina ŭ miesiac u pamien na zabieśpiačeńnie biaśpieki žycharoŭ Tenneka.

Švarchafien - nievialikaja vioska, cikavaja svajoj historyjaj. Amal piaćsot hadoŭ tamu tut adbyłasia vialikaja bitva, i ruiny zamka i staraja vioska na ŭschodzie ad sielišča, mierkavana, usio, što fizična zastałosia ad taho kanfliktu. Sučasnaja vioska kvitnieje, ale naściarožana stavicca da čužyncaŭ z-za svajho stanovišča la Silvanii.

Naŭbonum - nievialikaja vioska na miažy Silvanii. Ludzi tut žyvuć hałoŭnym čynam za košt hadoŭli zbožžavych kultur, kab pracharčavać siabie, a ŭsie inšyja tavary nabyvajucca za košt prodažu liškaŭ uradžaju ci pracy. Bo vioska znachodzicca la Pryvidnyja Ŭzhorki, žychary časta turbujucca pra čužyncaŭ z uschodu, pryvidaŭ i niačyścikaŭ. Palavyja Nahladniki paŭroślikaŭ, viadoma, čas ad času spyniajucca ŭ sieliščy i patrulujuć ŭschodnija miežy Muuta.

Maleńki haradok Biułarchof niadaŭna viarnuŭsia ŭ łona śviatych, skinuŭšy svaich silvanski vaładaroŭ. Kult Biułoraka, boha zachodnich haradzkich bahnaŭ, zjaŭlajecca pieravažnaj vieraj žycharoŭ. Śviatary Biułoraka ŭziali na siabie kiravańnie horadam i jaho spravami, imknučysia da bolšaj padtrymki i reintehracyi z Šcirlandam. Horad maje čatyry nievialikija chramy, pryśviečanyja Biułoraku, Morru, Zihmaru i Šalli adpaviedna. Na zachadzie ad horada, pobač z Biułarchofskimi Bahnami, lažyć u ruinach stary zamak šlachcičaŭ.

Štiernist - kvitniejučaja lasnaja vioska, jakaja staić miž Hałodnym Lesam i Svarzijaj. Viaskovyja zarablajuć bolšuju častku svajho bahaćcia na vysiečcy miascovaha lesu i spłavie jaho pa Ešenšciru da Zihfrydofa na kirmaš. Ludzi tut vielmi addanyja Moru, časta zaklikajuć Krumkačych Rycaraŭ baranić ich ad Hoblinaŭ i inšych niebiaśpiekaŭ navakolnych lasoŭ ci pahroz, što zychodziać zdaloku.

Fierštajn - maleńkaja vioska, źmiescavanaja na paŭdniovym boku bahnistaha Morfiena, u basiejnie Ešenšcira. Tutejšyja vielmi izalavany ad navakolnaha śvietu, uzajemadziejničajuć ź Impieryjaj tolki padčas svaich padarožžaŭ u Zihfrydchof, dla prodažu sušanaj ryby. Fierštajny taksama viadomy jak vydatnyja strałki, jakija časta słužać łučnikami ci vyviednikami ŭ Krumkačych Rycaraŭ.

Kaŭnic - heta nievialikaja viosačka na krajnim poŭdni Šcirlanda. Ludzi tut zarablajuć na žyćcio ŭ asnoŭnym apracoŭkaj uzhorystych ziemlaŭ, što atačajuć ich horad, a taksama zdabyčaj rudy z ziamli. Bolšasć padarožnikaŭ i ich tavaraŭ vitajucca ŭ Kaŭnicy, a Hnomy časta prajazdžajuć tut padčas svaich padarožžaŭ za miežy horaŭ ŭ šyrejšuju Impieryju. Adnak ludzi naściarožana staviacca da mudrahielistych ludziej i biez vahańniaŭ prahaniajuć łahiery Stryhanaŭ ci inšaje padobnaje śmiećcie sa svajoj chaty.

Marburh - maleńkaja viosačka na šlachu miž Vurtbadam i Zihfrajdchofam. Vioska viadoma svaimi śvińniami i ŭradžajami, jakija mohuć dapamahčy pracharčavać šmatlikija blizkija hramady i harady paśla dobraha ŭradžaju. Na žal, blizkasć vioski da Vialikaha Lesu aznačaje častyja ŭvarvańni jaho nasielnikaŭ i, adpaviedna, nižejšyja ŭradžai.

Zihmarynhien - pieršy z siami chramaŭ Zihmara, jaki idzie pa zychodnamu šlachu, što prajšoŭ pieršy impieratar u čornyja hory, kab zabić Šaranoraka, pieršanarodžanaha Drakonavaha Ohra. Tutejšyja žychary zarablajuć bolšuju častku svaich hrošaŭ, prymajučy pilihrymaŭ i zabiaśpiečvajučy ich ježaj i ryštunkam dla pachodu ŭ hory.

Viordarn is a small town hidden between mountains and valleys. The rough terrain makes expansion near impossible, but the intersection of the Stary Šlach Hnomaŭ and the Prager strasse makes passing along viable; not that it matters, as no outsider finds kindness in Viorden. The odd muutlandy can occasionally be seen purchasing supplies for the road, but its main attraction is the Viorden Meat and Cattle auction house. Its the only town in Šcirland that can be smelled before it is seen.

Kielchem is isolated among the hills of the Stary Šlach Hnomaŭ. Its secluded location allows the inhabitants to peacefully farm wheat and other cereals. Its golden fields go just about the start of Les Altern, where the fertility of the land drops inexplicably. Whatever is not used for local consumption is sent out along the Muut Road to the rest of eastern Šcirland and, ultimately, the Muutland.

Marbierh Castle lies to the south of Mittlenburh near the pilgrim trail leading to the seven temples of Šaranorak. The castle was erected to safeguard the passes leading out of the Hory Rohu Śvietu for Dwarf traders as well as to watch over the territory north of the Black Fire Pass.
Hipfel, A small village in the heart of the Greenleaf Hills.

The town of Drakienchof was once considered a beacon of culture within the Empire. But after the sinister takeover of Silvanija by the Vampire Counts, the formerly tall and inspiring spires of Castle Drakienchof now loom menacingly over the townspeople of Drakienchof. The people of Drakienchof are oppressed under the thumb of the fon Carstein lineage. They use the town of Drakienchof to hide their dangerous and other worldly possessions. The people exist as snacks for passing vampires. And every dark corner is the lair for myraid and unspeakable evils. Praying on the townsfolk from dusk till dawn.

Nachthafien is a very uninteresting place. Which is just as its ruler Hrafinia Gabriella fon Bundebad prefers. Nachthafien does not get involved in the petty squabbles of vampiric intrigue. Nor does it seek war with the Empire. It exists purely as a quiet, normal village. With nothing to see here. Just tasty villagers minding their business until it is time for the masters to feed.

Folburh was the site of a minor rebellion by mortal villagers against their vampiric overlord. Despite gruesomely ripping apart Hraf Aduhl fon Kohnfried with his dying breath he left a curse. The flesh of the villagers began slowly rotting away. But their lives would not leave this mortal coil. The villagers found themselves eternal slaves to a dead master. Now they are maddened skeletons roaming their old dwellings. Pretending to a cheap parody of life. And you better not remind them of what they are.

Hierchof does not sleep. Its paranoid vampire Hraf Johan fon Goal has forbidden it. A trickster Crone allegedly put a curse on the count. But none other than the Hraf himself can verify this. It has been said that a sleeping mortal would slay fon Goal in a brutal fashion. So fon Goal banned sleep. The mortal citizens are skittish. Sneaking an hour or twos nap in the dark corners of the city. Ordered to be ever watchful for the one who would slay their fearful ruler.

There are tales of Castle Tempłchof. At one point in history it was the home of the cruel Hrafinia Emanuelle fon Tempłchof. During a dark and terrible battle with the Hnomy besieging her home Hrafinia Emanuelle bathed her castle in profane magic. Causing an everlasting night to envelop the surrounding area. The indomitable Hnomy persisted however. Despite many losses they slew the wicked Hrafinia within Castle Tempłchof. Her anguished screams were said to echo throughout the halls long after the Hnomy left runes to repel dark magic. Recently, it has become known that some of those runes have faded. And dark things stir within the castle again. Lead by a chorus of screams.

The town of Tempłchof has seen many nightmarish things. Formerly under the auspices of the Vampire Hrafinia Emanuelle fon Tempłchof the village has recently become the home to a group of Light Mages. Whilst the townsfolk cling to these people as saviours they still whisper of a phantom. The tale of Whispering Nell is well known amongst the townsfolk. A foul spectre who haunts the town and surrounding area. Stealing children and killing Men. Almost as if she owns the place.

Vanchaldienchof is a miserable blot on the map of Silvanija. Originally constructed to guard the castle of Vanhaldenschlosse and its master, the Necromancer Frederick van Hal. After that castle fell into ruin the village remained as an area for the vampires of Silvanija to feed on its inhabitants and torment them. The villagers treated as little more than free roaming cattle.

Yet another blighted and miserable place. The villagers treated as little more than snacks from nearby fon Carsteins. Though rebellion has fermented in Mikalsdorf it has been put down so many times that the villagers are wretched, sad things. Shuffling around with no hope for any rescue.

Though unassuming at first, Chundam is a place of whispered rumours. It is said that the dead walk freely on its streets. As if mimicking the appearance of life. Others say puppets dance the night away, stringless and alive somehow. No one knows for sure for few have braved its narrow streets, its dusty shops, or its surprisingly open and inviting tavern. But all who go near have warned others to never approach Chundam in the night. For that is when bands of Vampires emerge to dance and make merry. And theyd just love to have a flushed and oh so juicy mortal to dance with.

Fort Vobierštar was once a small but mighty fortress of the Empire. Built shortly after the defeat of Vlad fon Carstein in the siege of Altdorf during one of the great Vampire wars of 2010 IC. However, many centuries later after neglect and lack of manpower the fortress was easily taken by Konrad fon Carstein. Though the Empire reclaimed the fort it was taken again many years later by Mannfred fon Carstein. Who put a terrible curse on the fort. Whenever it is sieged the wrathful specters of past wars rise to kill any and all who threaten the fort. Those spirits lay claim to the fort. And the Empire has been unsuccessful at reclaiming it since.

The oddest thing about Murieste is that its people do not follow the religion of Zihmar. Nor any other state approved religion. In fact, the lowly villagers of Murieste worship the vampires around them as gods. Coverting their dark power and hoping to become one of their dark kin. The Vampires in the area tolerate this. Seeing the pathetic peasants as amusing cattle. Vampires do love to play with their food.

Known for being a favourite haunt of Vampires looking to drag their victims off for a good torture session, the screams heard from Fort Brachier can be heard for miles around. Brachier is often fought over by Vampire counts. All of them looking for a new lair from which to torment Men of the Empire.

Most Vampire Counts leave Štuudchof alone, It has been ruled efficiently as a slaughterhouse for human cattle by its ruler. From the outside it simply looks like another mud covered village in the middle of this desolate land. From which very little is known about.

Renowned for its tapestries made of human flesh. Nachtšłoss is a place of wanton butchery and desolation. With darkness around every corner and in every hall of its cursed interior. Monsters freely roam the corridors. Looking for new victims to try their latest stitching patterns on.
Hałłchof is often a favourite haunt of Brettonian Blood Knights. Used as a training camp and feasting hall for these bloodthirsty creatures.

Zenkchof is one of the last bastions of free humans in Sylvannia. Despite officially being under the dominion of the Vampire Counts, human adventurers and crusaders often use Zenkchof and its surrounding town to stage conflicts against their vampiric masters. Or at least as a base from which to look for treasure.

Zenkchof is one of the last bastions of free humans in Sylvannia. Despite officially being under the dominion of the Vampire Counts, human adventurers and crusaders often use Zenkchof and its surrounding town to stage conflicts against their vampiric masters. Or at least as a base from which to look for treasure.

Mere months before the Vampire wars. A sorcerer of Nurgle cursed the surrounding village with a plague. The nobility of Vartenchof barricaded themselves in the castle. The villagers begged for salvation as their flesh swelled and burst from deadly boils. But the nobility cared little for them. Inside the castle, the nobles slowly went insane. Becoming cultists of Nurgle within their isolated walls. They were slain by the Vampires as they took over Sylvannia. But the scars of Nurgles rot still remain.

As the nobles of Vartenchof locked themselves away, the blighted souls of Vartenchof village slowly succumbed to the sickness of Nurgles Rot. Many simply died. They were lucky. For Nurgle sees his sickness as a blessing and gift. And one must be alive to experience it all. When the Vampire Counts came for Vartenchof, the few villages left gladly bound themselves to vampiric service in exchange for a cure. As their service wavers the rot returns. So the Villagers do their best to remain loyal.

This swampy village is isolated from most of Sylvannia. Crossable only by boat, the houses are on stilts and it is very hard for any vampire to find purchase within Sumpdorf. The villagers and farmers know they are safe from the zombies that haunt the Dark Moor. But the local Vampire Counts still come by air from Vartenchof Castle to collect the blood tax.

Hryśsienvald is the northernmost settlement in Vissenland, right along the banks of the Rajk. South of the beginning of the Vorbergland Canal System as well as the southern extent of the Rajkvald forest. The Dwarf Shanty, ‘Kazid Slumbol sits against the south side of its palisade, and is mostly home to transient Dwarf traders and caravanners, resting here with their more permanent kin before continuing on their routes. Many hunters, trappers and woodcutters make their residence here and during the day will go north into the Rajkvald to make their living. The Southern Rajkvald is known for being particularly infested with monsters and neer do wells. As a result the ruler of Hryśsienvald, Hraf Bruno Pfeifraucher, is a professional military man who is often seen leading a patrol around his town to keep the forests dangers at bay.

Rochrhaŭzen is an isolated Visenlander village known for its excellent vineyards, popular even in some of the best taverns in Nuln. This is in part thanks to the cool waters of the River Griss, which come out of the mountains near Rochrhaŭzen.

Viśsienburh is the capital of Vissenland and, while it might not carry the economic or cultural weight of Nuln, it is truly the centre of the people. The folk here are the epitome of those virtues which makes Visenlanders unique from the rest of the Empire. The boughers, artisans and labourers go about their business with thrift and daur pragmatism, speaking clearly and in short direct sentences. Unlike in Altdorf or Nuln, the people here have no time for poetic or flowery expressions. Most of the citizens work the various temples in the city into their daily routine, picking one each day and paying their respect if only for a few minutes, allowing them to pay respect to most of the principal gods each week. Viśsienburh is also the last stop for river trade on the upper Rajk before Nuln and is surrounded by good farmland. Elector-Hrafinia Emmanuelle fon Liebwitz seldom journeys to Viśsienburh, coming only to meet the ‘po-faced boughers which sit on the Assembly of Vissenland. As a result, while the town is ruled in her name, Baranesa Toppenheimer has been given more and more control over the province as a whole.

On the Border of the Grey Mountains, along the shores of the River Wissen is the village of Dotternbach. The Visenlanders here are shepherds used to climbing high into the lands west of their homes, and as such make strong recruits when they have the young men to spare.
Chalhierbach is an isolated Visenlander village right on the traditional border with Old Zolland. It sits on the shores of the River Wissen, which the people here use to irrigate their crops.
On the western shore of the River Soll, at one of the only nearby ferries across the river, is the village of Durbchajm. The Sollanders here tend sheep to provide wool to nearby Fajldorf.

Biernaŭ is your typical Sollander village; the people here are mostly shepherds who raise sheep for their wool. They sell this wool at nearby Fajldorf for a decent price and are happy with their modest living.

On the eastern shore of the River Soll is the Sollander village of Zeksaŭ. The people here are not very well off, and typically can only grow enough food to feed themselves. What extra they do produce is taken to market at Fajldorf.

Across the River Soll from Krojtcchafien is the small village of Vajlerbierh. The closeness of the two communities results in a great many ties between them. For instance the town grave digger for Krojtcchafien, Boris Hippler, makes his residence here in Vajlerbierh.

The Sollanders of Zerryh are simple people and are proud of it. Asking any of the shepherds here if they have any greater aspirations than sheep will elicit a round of laughter followed by the statement that: ‘my family has been here since the fall of Zolland, not even a Daemon could make me abandon our trade!

Avinhien is a small Visenlander farming community on the shore of the lower River Soll, just south of a small marshy confluence caused by the lower Soll meeting with the Soll. The people here sell much of their grain to nearby Karak Norn in return for coin and drink, though they will sell you what grain they have to spare.

Chajzienbierh is well renowned for its deep red wines, which are shipped and sold from Fajldorf to Kislev. The Visenlander winemakers here credit the upper River Soll for irrigating their land, as well as the fair winds out of the Granite pass, for the quality of their fruit.

Along the shore of the lower River Soll is the village of Aŭhien. At one time this land would have been populated by Sollanders, but today this part of Sudenland is home to Visenlanders. The people here can trace their roots back at least three centuries and are very experienced farmers. Aŭhien is well used by passersby, as the village sits on the Granite Pass road, the main route between Majssen and Karak Norn.
Kielhard is a small Visenlander village on the western shore of the upper Soll. The people here mostly mine the nearby mountains for Iron ore.

To the north of Hiešburh is Flurn, an old Sollander village that has been on the maps since before the fall of Zolland. The people here carry on the traditions of Zolland, and even have a small shrine to Myrmidia.

To the south of Hiešburh is Altchaŭzen, a Sollander village populated mostly by shepherds. The land here is also good for vineyards, and while the Altchaŭzen vintage hasnt become renowned outside of the region, it is well received in Hiešburh.

Zochtenaŭ is a relatively new community, established within the last few generations as an attempt by the people of Zolland to restore some of their former glory. Like many Sollanders, they seem to carry the weight of their past on their backs and in their bones, but they take pride in their work and look after their sheep with thrift and efficiency.

Štajnhart was once a moderately sized city. With the destruction of old Zolland, what remains of Štajnhart today is but a husk of what used to be. Around the present day town can be found the eight hundred year old ruins. In Štajnhart, the oppressive air that hangs around the Sollanders is the heaviest, as if theyd be happier if they could just forget their former grandeur. To the south of Štajnhart is a set of ancient standing stones, commonly called ‘Tals Fangs. This name is in spite of the insistence of the cult of Taal that the site is not Talite in origin. A ferry across the River Oggel is here, in the direction of Miendielchof.
Near Waldbach is the small Visenlander settlement of Moasach. The people of Moasach provide for themselves by raising pigs.

Within sight of the wall in Ahbajtien is the Visenlander village of Balenchof. The people here are friendly, but have a deep mistrust of Averlanders, saying: ‘they refuse to evr sign a contract, take me at my word they say, on their ‘oner they say. I tell em if Im to take em on their ‘oner, then I need the Crowns and Shillings now!

Irrigated by the River Soll, the Sollanders here at Ajhienchof are able to grow a large quantity of grain and other foodstuffs, which they often take to Wursterburg to be loaded onto a ship and sold farther north.
Nestled in the hills to the northwest of Vusterburh is the Sollander village of Rötenbach. The people here are mostly shepherds, and have been known to range their sheep as far as Zerryh.
Zalmfahr is a small Visenlander farming community along the shores of the upper River Soll. It is protected from danger by nearby Nihren.
Trulbien is a small Sollander village that primarily gets by through the wool trade. The shepherds here often work with the shepherds of Rotienbach and Zerryh.

Near the mountainous source of the River Sonne is the village of Šarmbiek. The people here are hardy mountain dwelling Sollanders, who make their living either by working in the mine at nearby Tierhügel or by raising cattle in the small plain to the northwest of the settlement. On the rise just north of the village centre is a ring of ancient standing stones.
On the Zonnfurt-Wursterburg road is the village of Talfanh, which cuts timber and entertains passerbys.

Mierfield is a village in the Vohieland and as a result is part of the land held in dispute between Averland and Vissenland. To the north of Mierfield is the bridge over the upper Rajk to Hocheleben, to the south is the village of Jenhien.

Jenhien is a small community in the Vohieland that in recent years has found itself in the middle of a dispute between Vissenland and Averland. By an ancient treaty the division between Vissenland and Averland is set south of the upper River Rajk and fifty leagues east of the River Oggel. Unfortunately, the upper Rajk is known to change its course regularly and leagues are no longer used in the Empire in favour of the Imperial Mile. The fertile, well watered grasslands of the Oggeland is greatly desired by both the Vissenland Sheep Herders, and the Averland Cattle Ranchers; brawls or even ‘battles have been known to commence between the two groups. Rancher and Herder alike have petitioned their lords to settle this dispute, with the sword if need be.

Vosterciel is formerly recognized as part of Vissenland, the fort at Miendielchof is there to insure this. Despite these legal realities, the people of Vosterciel have always maintained a greater kinship with Averlanders than they have with Visenlanders or even Sollanders. Should Averland choose to act on the Vohieland dispute, the people of Vosterciel would support them.
Pal is a Sollander village. The people here are mostly shepherds and rely on the production of wool to make ends meet.

Travellers heading by the Icy Wind Pass to or from Karak Hirn inevitably pass through Kroppienlibien. Many choose to stop here and spend the night before continuing their journey. The small community of Kroppienlibien has no qualms with providing these travellers with shelter, or selling them the furs that local hunters have collected this season. Kroppienlibien is on the shores of the River Hornberg, just after the River Aulen has contributed to its flow.
Bidernaŭ is a Sollander village just north across the Soll from Vusterburh. The people here produce just enough food to feed themselves, taking what little they have to spare to market at Vusterburh.
Forcen is a small community of Visenlander foresters, who provide wood for many of the nearby settlements.
Maŭchien is a small community of Visenlander foresters, they are known particularly well in Vupiertal, where most of their wood is shipped across the Rajk for cutting.
On the road to Štajh and Viśsienburh from Erbšaŭen is the small fishing village of Elvanhien, whose name comes from an ancient legal requirement for road construction.

A run-down pest hole inhabited by the poorest of the poor, alcoholism and crime are rampant here. The population has around 1200 kislevite immigrants who live in their own slice of heaven called little kislev. The kislevites and the local talabeclanders dont really interact much.

Upstream of the river Uckro, The villagers of Tojpic are a tight knit community, where everyone adds to the needs of each other. They dont get many visitors and those that do visit often come to trade for wood from the local lumber mill.

Close to the treeline of the forest that touches Tałabchajms crater wall. The villagers of Dreec keep cows, many shepherds and some veterinarians take care of the great herd of cattle that graze in and around the fields of Dreec.

Near the mouth of the river Lochra, hence the name, the villagers of Łochrafurt are farmers and pig herders. Water is often carried through the village from the river to provide for the fields and the many pigs that bathe in the mud pits around the village.

A fishing village that borders the river Talabec. Vienau is surrounded by tents that bear the colours of Ostland. However the village of Vienau doesnt give the ostlanders the treatment that Biek gives them. Even though they outnumber the locals, the village elder has put the immigrants to work, either aiding in the fishing, forming hunter groups, with the local śviatars blessing of course, or farmers.
A small village with a stretch of the Vialiki Les to the east and a few hills to the south. Its villagers are mainly woodcutters and eke out a decent existence trading said timber.

Bordering the river Lochra on two sides, Ertburh enjoys the natural protection the river offers from the west and the south. Ertburh is a diverse village, with some hunters, some farmers, some fishermen and a few śviatary who tend to a small chapel of Taal.

A bustling town along the river Šcir and the river kölpin with many of the local populace consisting of woodcutters. Theres alot of taverns for the woodcutters to take a load off after work and all of them are named after the job their patrons have. They have Mourners guild, which is dedicated to the Cult of Morr, and is responsible for organising funerals and seeing to the upkeep of the local graveyard.

An unassuming farming village east of the river kölpin, no road leads to Sabritz, instead farmers follow the river south to reach Hiersdorch. They dont care much about this, for they prefer solitude and are quite suspicious of strangers.

Separated from the Barren Hills by a stretch of the Vialiki Les, Pryštlichajm is home to a large Zihmarite monastery, the Temple of Leopold “the Hammer of Faith.” The brothers here are dedicated to the study and eventual eradication of whatever curses the Barren Hills. Although they will explore the hills themselves, they also hire adventurers if other matters demand their attention. The monastery also hunts down any Mutants that wander north out of the hills.

Harndorf is a fortified village with its back to the river Talabec and one side bordering the River Karwe. Harndorf enjoys its natural protection, its land borders protected by a stone wall, Harndorf has a solid strategic position. One can enter Harndorf through a portcullis in the wall or through a ferry across the river Talabec.

The southernmost village of Volhien. Its villagers maintain a big herd of sheep that graze near the barren hills. Despite Pryštlichajms efforts to stop the supposed hauntings from the barren hills, the odd sheep still goes missing now and again. Despite this the herd remains quite large.

Bordering the river Šcir and being at the centre of a crossroads, Missen sees alot of traffic from the surrounding villages. Missen has bits of forest a few ways away and the local populace earns a decent living trading timber.
A community of tree lovers as theyre often described, they give praise to Taal and only use the wood of dead trees, they get by on their meagre farms and foraging in the Vialiki Les.

A long way from other towns and villages the village of Aśsino is quite poor, despite its decent food stocks. It sees a decent amount of traffic from anyone that comes and goes from Ostermark and sometimes people that travel down the river Šcir, but not many wish to stay long in such a desolate looking place. Many requests have been sent to Hiermsdorf for tools and supplies to fix the village but not much has been set in motion as of yet.

A village close to a small bit of forest and surrounded by small hills. The villagers of Badaŭ have many farms close to the base of the hills to utilize rainwater flowing down the hills for irrigation.

Bordering a great swathe of the Vialiki Les the villagers of Chorna are mainly hunters and woodsmen. Chorna earns a decent amount of money from the meat and hides they sell and give praise to Taal for it.
Slightly wealthier in terms of food and coin than most villages in Talabecland. Klepcyh enjoys the protection Castle Ravienštajn provides.

Tucked in between two parts of the Vialiki Les, Zuryn houses a decent amount of Taal worshippers, often going on pilgrimage to Tałabchajm or answering Tals call. The Fishermen of Zuryn often walk north towards the river Uckro to fish, enjoying the walk in the Vialiki Les as they do so. Those that remain keep themselves busy with the worship of Taal and tending the farms.

Frederchajm is a small Rajklander village just north of Altdorf on the Altdorf-Midienchajm road. While the town is a possession of Karl-Franz and is a part of Altdorfs demesne, the Emperor has seen fit to give oversight of it in all but name to the Cult of Šalla. This is a result of the cults request for an area in which to establish a walled hospice and sanatorium.

On the eastern side of the confluence of the rivers Taal and Rajk sits the village of Kaldach. The town is notable particularly for being the demarcation of the Rajkland/Talabecland border. Besides this, it remains a small farming community.

Directly west of Altdorf, between the river Rajk and the Vajssbruk canal is the village of Hochłof. The town is known for the type of grain it raises the Hochloffkorn which is very well regarded for making a high quality flour.

Cholthuzen is a town in western Rajkland on the river Schilder. By road it lies between Ajlchart and Šyldierchajm. The towns primary trade good is the Cholthuzen Hogshead barrel which is used across the empire to age or ferment their products before shipment. The barrels are said to be so sturdy as to be able to protect their contents even from direct cannon fire. Every year Cholthuzen hosts the Weinfest, a great gathering for wine tasting that requires an invite to enter. Of course the lack of invite does not stop the horde of wastrels and rogues who wish to drink the free wine provided by the festival. Weinfest also marks the only time of year during which the Golden Cask is brought out, which is said to contain the best wine in the Empire if not the entire Old World. Due to the towns forested location, it is frequently attacked by beastmen. The palisades and guards are normally strong enough to see the monsters off, but the townspeople fear the day this defence falls short. As such, some of the townspeople have been leaving casks of cheap wine at the edge of the woods in an attempt to appease the beastmen with tribute. This dubious practice likely will not be allowed to continue much longer.

Ajlchart remains its mark on the map for one reason; the popularity of its vintage of white wine. Ajlchart wine is one of the Rajklands best wines, valued for its crisp light flavours and its mild hangovers. Ajlchart is a destination for riverboat cruises, where wealthy merchants and nobles from Altdorf often come up the river to taste the various local vintages and foods. Many of the people here are said to have bretonnian heritage, visitors often comment on the similar bone structure shared by many of the inhabitants.

Uśsinhien is a small village located on the road between Cholthuzen and Vośburh. The town is at the furthest point that the River Schilder remains navigable by barge, meaning that many shipments bound for Chielmhart will arrive first here. The people here raise crops along the river Schilder and will venture into the nearby Grey Mountains to mine seams of ore. The town is well protected by the walls at Chielmhart, and really only worries about the denizens of the Rajkvald.
Morlenfurt is a small village near the headwaters of the river Bogen. The town is known for its silver mines and the small community of Hnomy which contribute to the silver trade within the Rajkland.

At the foot of the Axe Bite Pass sits the village of Vośburh, the last Imperial settlement before the Market fortress of Chielmhart and the Imperial/Bretonnian border. Any shipments bound for Chielmhart must pass first through Vośburh, and this source of trade makes the merchants here fairly prosperous.

To the north northwest of Biohienchafien is the timber producing village of Chiercchald. Situated deep in the Rajkvald, Chiercchald is known for the quality and lengths of its timber samples, much of which is sent to Biohienchafien and Hriunburh for their boatbuilding.

Hrajssbach is a forest village just north of Ubieršrajk. The people here carefully timber the woods nearby and grow what crops they can in the clearings around the village. For a long time there have been rumors and worries about a dark estate just east of the village, which is said to house great evil.

To the south of Ubieršrajk is the mining town of Chuhieldal. Chuhieldal was founded three hundred years after the founding of the empire to mine copper and iron from the Grey mountains. In 1112 IC, town records indicate that the Black Plague devastated the local population and nearly ruined the town. The cult of Šalla saw fit to establish a hospice here shortly thereafter. Not long after the arrival of the Šallans, the Stryhany that have always frequented the area were banned from entering the town. Despite this they regularly pitch camp outside of the palisade to entertain and trade with the locals
Barfschajm is a small village along the river Hryśsien near the Hrafinia Emmanuelle canal. Its grain often is exported out of the Rajkland to feed Hryśsienvald and Nuln.

Štajndorf is a small village near the headwaters of the river Hryśsien. Its people refuse to travel into the Grey Mountains that often overshadow the village. Despite the fact that the minerals would bring great wealth to the village, the people here speak of a dread castle in the mountains above them, saying that they would rather remain in their vale with their grain.

Naffdorf is an isolated village that sits along the Grey Lady Canal between Šcimmihien and Chuhieldal. Naffdorf is almost entirely surrounded by a marshland created by the nearby rivers Teufel, Ober and Tranig. In truth there is not much reason to stop in Naffdorf, the villages main commodity is the fish that use the canals to move between the rivers.

Tajfielfojer is a rural village outside of Kiempierbad. The village is truly only notable for being the scene where one hundred years ago the forces of the Rajkland Clashed with one of the largest hordes of Beastmen to emerge from the Rajkvald Forest. The story goes that when the battle wizards through their magical fire towards the monstrosities, the trees around them burst into a devils fire with hues not natural to this world. The people here are proud of this story and often hawk the ‘relics of this historic battle.

Dzisdorf is a small town on the river Rajk located between Altdorf and Kiempierbad. Dzisdorf is a major holy site of the Cult of Zihmar, it is said that Magnus the Pious once made a powerful and stirring speech to the crowds who had gathered to hear him. Around sixty years ago, Emperor Wilhelm III founded the Dzisdorf Military college to train those who have proven their leadership abilities in battle.

Lachienbad sits along the Tranig river at the joining points of the Grey Lady and Ober-Šcimmihien canals. While the village is a farming community, it is the home of a talented blacksmith, Uli and his promisingly talented son Valten.

Vorlic is a river village protected by the forces garrisoning the Zamak Rajkshard. The people here are very loyal directly to the Emperor Karl-Franz who many believe to be a reincarnation of Zihmar. The town benefits from trade heading down the Rajk to Altdorf, Maryjenburh and beyond.

The town of Hriunburh sits on the river Teufel. While trade flows through the town from the canals to itself and from the Rajk to its north, Hriunburhs main source of wealth comes from its river boatyards, where many of the boats and barges that ply the rivers of the Rajkland originate from. The town is also famous for the Battle of Hriunburh where the advance of Orc Warlord Gorbad Ironclaw was finally halted around a half a millenia ago. The battle plains is valued particularly due to the fact that nearly all of the Imperial and orc forces present were mounted calvarymen, unusual for both the contemporary period and the modern era. As such an excavation site has been established by several interested parties and many come to look upon their work.

Vajssbruk sits on the joining of the Vajssbruk Canal and the river Bӧgen. The town once was a major source of coal and iron in the Rajkland, the mining of which provided the Gruber family with enough funds to construct the Vajssbruk Canal, which enabled easier transportation of the mined material to market. Now the mines have mostly been depleted and while the town continues to have prosperous ventures in trade thanks to the canal, the many former workers of the mine have found themselves unemployed and stuck in Vajssbruk, where they spend their time drinking cheap alcohol and causing trouble.
Just to the south west of Altdorf is the small village of Chajlihien. The village is nothing to speak of, but it is near the amber hills, which offer a spectacular view of Altdorf from their height.

Rajnsfield is a village along the Uhl river in the northwestern Rajkvald. The people here are fairly isolated from the rest of the Province, relying on what little trade passes by on the road towards Maryjenburh.
